Line 12: Line 12:  
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is concerned with how one ought to live. Morality is also described as the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are interpreted to be either "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or [[wrong]]). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.)consisting of absolute rules that cannot be broken. A ''moral'' is a lesson or teaching that places moral decisions within context. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness" although the common usage of the term in such a context assumes that any morality is good or right, but morality, or how one ought to live, is up to individual choices. Arguably personal definitions of "good" and "bad," are arbitrary, subjective, constrained by time, influenced by self-interest and rationalization, and widely varied.
 
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is concerned with how one ought to live. Morality is also described as the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are interpreted to be either "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or [[wrong]]). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.)consisting of absolute rules that cannot be broken. A ''moral'' is a lesson or teaching that places moral decisions within context. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness" although the common usage of the term in such a context assumes that any morality is good or right, but morality, or how one ought to live, is up to individual choices. Arguably personal definitions of "good" and "bad," are arbitrary, subjective, constrained by time, influenced by self-interest and rationalization, and widely varied.
    −
''Immorality'' is the perception by one's self or other people that one lacks morality, based on their own conception of morality, and so is a criticism that is arguably mere disapproval, a label. Immorality is not the intentional opposition to that which is considered good or right, a claim that assumes that people choose to be immoral for the sake of disregarding morality for the sake of it, when their actions may simply be based on necessity, history, habits, environment. ''[[Amorality]]'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
+
''Immorality'' is the perception by one's self or other people that one lacks morality, based on their own conception of morality, and so is a criticism that is arguably mere disapproval, a label. Immorality is not the intentional opposition to that which is considered good or right, a claim that assumes that people choose to be immoral for the sake of disregarding morality, merely for the sake of it, when their actions may simply be based on necessity, history, habit, environment.
−
{{Cite book| last = Johnstone | first = Megan-Jane | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Bioethics: A Nursing Perspective | publisher = Elsevier Health Sciences | year = 2008 | location = | pages = 102–103 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-7295-3873-2 }}And example is an android, who is not a moral agent who can choose to do the right thing, but a computer machine that follows only explicit commands from human programmers. Androids lack morality. Likewise, choosing between chocolate or vanilla is not a moral choice, but one that is amoral, does not raise ethical questions. Does not obligate one to consider the interests of others who could be affected. Importantly "amoral" should not be confused with meaning "lacking morals," "antisocial," or "criminally corrupt." Amoral descriptions regard cases and actions that carry no moral obligation or duty by being devoid of any moral quandary.
+
  +
''[[Amorality]]'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>

An example is an android, who is not a moral agent who can choose to do the right thing, but a computer machine that follows only explicit commands from human programmers. Androids lack morality. Likewise, choosing between chocolate or vanilla is not a moral choice, but one that is amoral, does not raise ethical questions. Does not obligate one to consider the interests of others who could be affected. Amoral descriptions regard cases and actions that carry no moral obligation or duty by being devoid of any moral quandary.

{{cite web| url = http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/amorality | title = Amorality | accessdate = 2010-06-18 | work = Dictionary.com}} "having no moral standards, restraints, or principles; unaware of or indifferent to questions of right or wrong." An android could be considered to be amoral, that are not moral agents who can choose their decisions. Since androids are computer machines which follow explicit programmed actions written as human commands, they lack morality, are amoral, without morality. Amorality should not be confused with terms like "sociopath," lacking any guilt or conscience regarding their personal behavior. The choice between chocolate or vanilla is an amoral decision, where one is not held responsible for considering the interests of others affected by one's actions.
+
{{cite web| url = http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/amorality | title = Amorality | accessdate = 2010-06-18 | work = Dictionary.com}} "having no moral standards, restraints, or principles; unaware of or indifferent to questions of right or wrong." An android could be considered to be amoral, that are not moral agents who can choose their decisions. Since androids are computers and computers only do as they are programmed to do, they lack any choice and so they lack morality, are amoral, without morality. Amorality should not be confused with terms like "sociopath" (lacking any guilt or conscience regarding their personal behavior). The choice between chocolate or vanilla is an another amoral decision, where one is not held responsible for considering the interests of the others affected by one's actions.
     
</ref> An example of a moral code is the Hebrew [[10 commandments]], a list of absolute rules regarding what god demands. The [[Golden Rule]] is however, not an example of a moral code, but a guideline that states that, "One should treat others as one would like others to treat oneself."<ref name = "Flew">{{Cite encyclopedia |title=golden rule|editor =[[Antony Flew]] | encyclopedia=A Dictionary of Philosophy | publisher = [[Pan Books]] in association with [[Macmillan Publishers|The MacMillan Press]] | year = 1979 | location = London | page = 134 | isbn = 9780333262047 }} This dictionary of philosophy contains the following exact quote under the entry for "golden rule": "The maxim 'Treat others how you wish to be treated'. Various expressions of this oft-cited moral rule are to be found in tenets of most religions and creeds through the ages, testifying to its universal applicability." (end quote)</ref> However, some have evaluated the Golden Rule as a rule of practicality.
 
</ref> An example of a moral code is the Hebrew [[10 commandments]], a list of absolute rules regarding what god demands. The [[Golden Rule]] is however, not an example of a moral code, but a guideline that states that, "One should treat others as one would like others to treat oneself."<ref name = "Flew">{{Cite encyclopedia |title=golden rule|editor =[[Antony Flew]] | encyclopedia=A Dictionary of Philosophy | publisher = [[Pan Books]] in association with [[Macmillan Publishers|The MacMillan Press]] | year = 1979 | location = London | page = 134 | isbn = 9780333262047 }} This dictionary of philosophy contains the following exact quote under the entry for "golden rule": "The maxim 'Treat others how you wish to be treated'. Various expressions of this oft-cited moral rule are to be found in tenets of most religions and creeds through the ages, testifying to its universal applicability." (end quote)</ref> However, some have evaluated the Golden Rule as a rule of practicality.
